title: Shane Van Gisbergen Extends NASCAR Stay With Trackhouse Racing Deal
description: Shane Van Gisbergen turned a surprise debut win into a career that’s seems to be only getting started.
content:
In NASCAR news that would be shocking if it didn’t happen, Trackhouse Racing announced a contract extension with Shane van Gisbergen Friday.

But this isn’t a one-off dip-your-toes in the NASCAR waters deal, it’s a multiyear contract extension meaning the likable New Zealander isn’t going anywhere anytime soon. It all started with a one-off race with Trackhouse’s Project91 in 2023 that ended with SVG in victory lane and set him on a course to race in NASCAR.

"I feel like Trackhouse Racing is my home," said the 36-year-old Van Gisbergen, who's been proclaimed the greatest NASCAR road racer in history in some circles.

"Trackhouse gave me the opportunity to race at Chicago in 2023. That was just a one-race deal, and everything that has happened since then is because of the chance Justin (Marks, Trackhouse founder and owner) took on me. The men and women at Trackhouse have helped me feel at home in this new challenge, and I've been loving every minute of it. We still have a lot of work to do, but I couldn't be happier."

The team couldn’t be happier either. After all, the former Australian Supercars champion became the first driver since Johnny Rutherford in 1963 to win his first Cup Series start.

But that win in Chicago was only just the start. After a year spent under a development contract with Trackhouse, he raced full-time with Kaulig Racing in the Xfinity Series in 2024. He did make 12 Cup series starts in 2024, but Trackhouse made room for him adding a third fulltime slot on their team, and he’s rewarded them handsomely.

Since that Chicago win in 2023 he’s added three more victories, all of those coming this year in his first full time Cup season with the Trackhouse. He won the inaugural Mexico City race, the Chicago Street Race again and at Sonoma. He also grabbed a Xfinity Series victory at the Chicago Street Race, driving for JR Motorsports.

Those Cup wins pushed his career total to four victories in just 37 career races. That makes him the quickest driver to score three wins in NASCAR’s modern era. And if you’re wondering who holds the record for most road course wins in Cup history… well, he’s got that too.

With all that what NASCAR team in their right mind wouldn’t want someone of SVG’s caliber signed for many more years. After all there aren’t many drivers capable of doing what he’s done: fly halfway across the planet, learn a completely different type of racing, and still make seasoned veterans look like they’ve left the parking brake on.

"We are getting to watch one of the superstars of racing," said team owner Justin Marks. "What we are asking him to do carries a high degree of difficulty. He's moved to the other side of the world, learned a new form of racing and at times dominated the competition. He's one of the greatest."

So SVG is here to say. He’s going to be celebrating wins, kicking signed rugby balls into the stands for many years to come and keeping competitors worried on every road course on the schedule.
summary: Shane van Gisbergen, a New Zealander racing driver, has been extended his contract with Trackhouse Racing for five years. The extension comes after a one-off race in 2023 that set him on a path to race in NASCAR. Since then, he has won three races, including the inaugural Mexico City race, the Chicago Street Race and at Sonoma. Van Gisburgen, who has also been declared the greatest NASCAR road racer in history, became the first driver since Johnny Rutherford in 1963 to win his first Cup Series start. He has also added three victories in just 37 career races, making him the quickest driver to score three wins in NASCAR's modern era.
shortSummary: Shane van Gisbergen extended his NASCAR contract with Trackhouse Racing, keeping him at the team for many years despite recent successes.

scraped_sources.text:
Once upon a time, 48 months ago, a little LLC with just $500 in the bank imagined shaking up the NASCAR world. Fast forward to Saturday at Daytona, and that dream is not just alive—it’s roaring. Trackhouse Racing, the team that’s been punching above its weight since inception, announced that they’re adding a third team. And to make things even more exciting, they’ve tapped Shane van Gisbergen—yes, the Aussie who stormed into NASCAR just two years ago—to be their latest full-time driver.
Since their formation Trackhouse teams have won seven races, one of those victories coming with the newest full-time driver: Shane van Gisbergen. For team owner Justin Marks, this expansion wasn’t just a happy accident—it was always part of the master plan.
“I’ve always thought that three teams is a really strong number of teams to have in this sport,” Marks said. “It just gives you 33% more of an opportunity on the racetrack every weekend. Frankly, it’s four-car teams are reserved for really, really big companies in this sport, and it’s tough to make four cars work.
“I think three was kind of always sort of the number for us from day one if things went our way and we could grow from one car to two, that three was kind of the goal. An opportunity be able to come up to expand to a third car for this year, so we took it.”
The journey to a fulltime spot in NASCAR’s top tier series for van Gisbergen actually began in a Trackhouse car as part of Trackhouse Racing Project 91 a part time effort that fields one-off entries featuring star drivers from other racing disciplines including 2007 Formula One World Champion Kimi Räikkönen. And van Gisbergen who will now realize his dream of racing fulltime in the top racing series in America. He will now approach 2025 and his spot on the full-time stage with a mix of pressure, motivation, anxiety, and excitement.
“But that’s why we do it,” the driver known as simply SVG explained. “Those feels are good things because it means you care so much about it, right? All this year, I’ve been nervous getting in the car. Anxious. How it’s going to go. How am I going to be? That’s an awesome feeling and something I haven’t had for a few years, so it’s been really cool. It’s cool to be energized like that. Of course there’s going to be pressure. The Cup Series is pretty cutthroat as we’ve seen. A lot of guys, it’s pretty hard to make it. I just have to keep learning, do the best I can, and I’ll be fine.”
A multi-time Supercars champion, van Gisbergen has been racing in the NASCAR Xfinity series for Kaulig Racing this season and has two wins in that series including adding another trophy from the Chicago Street course in July. Even he admits though he is still on a learning curve.
And the biggest challenge?
“Turning left,” he quips with a grin. Adding that NASCAR isn’t just about going fast in circles; it’s a sport full of variables—weather changes, rubber build-up, and the chaotic ballet of superspeedway racing. Even the best, like Kyle Larson, can go from first to 20th in a heartbeat. It’s all about instincts, and SVG is still honing his.
“You can prep all you want, but it’s having those instincts in how to react and having the best way to do it,” he said. “Every race, I’m learning something.”
Trackhouse Racing has secured a Charter for their new team, NASCAR’s equivalent of a Golden Ticket, guaranteeing entry into every Cup Series points race on the schedule. They’ve also locked in sponsorship, details of which will be announced later.
“There’s a lot of things falling in line,” Marks said. “We had to take advantage of that opportunity when it was here before we lost it. It wasn’t really that difficult of a decision.”
SVG’s new ride will sport the No. 88—yes, that No. 88. The one made famous by Dale Earnhardt Jr. during his time at Hendrick Motorsports. Marks didn’t just slap a sticker on the car, though; he made sure to get the blessing of NASCAR royalty.
“We talked to Dale Jr., and he was proud to see the number in good hands,” Marks said. “For us, it’s about legacy.”
In just a year and a half, SVG has gone from a virtual unknown in NASCAR to a future Cup driver, and Trackhouse has gone from a startup to a serious contender. “It’s a really cool team to be a part of,” SVG said. “There’s a lot of work ahead, but I’m pumped for the challenge.”
Trackhouse Racing may have started with $500, but they’ll soon be a three-car juggernaut, ready to make even more noise in 2025. And with SVG behind the wheel of the No. 88, the sky could very well be the limit.

Shane van Gisbergen is finally here. In America that is. The Australian Supercar champion has made the move to the United States and he along with his wife now reside in the heart of NASCAR country, Mooresville, North Carolina.
The New Zealand native left the comfort of his old life in Australia to race in NASCAR on a fulltime basis. This year he will get to race on all types of tracks, many of them ovals where he has little experience racing on having raced on only one oval, that in the Truck series race last year at Indianapolis Raceway Park.
He said he’s ready to gain more experience, especially at the intermediate tracks, two in particular.
“You know, everyone's talking about Vegas, turn one, and two how hard that's going to be for me,” he said. “And Darlington; probably those are the ones I'm most excited about.
“You know, I’m here for a challenge and I'm sure those tracks are going to be very difficult… I just want to get out there and feel what everyone's saying, how bad and tough it is, so it'll be interesting.”
While he will be racing on different styles of tracks, he will also need to adjust to different ways of dealing with his sponsors. And though he has only been through one full NASCAR Cup race weekend in America, he can already notice differences when it comes to sponsor commitments. When it came to sponsor commitments for an event in Australia it involved a great deal more.
“Like, we go to the track on a Tuesday,” he said. “And we're doing promotions all week and yeah, it's different.
“Whereas here you seem to do less, but you do more. You do bigger appearances, and it means much more, you know, you meet people…It seems to have much more meaning and productiveness so it's different but very good here.”
Another difference he’s seen so far is with the media here in the States.
“The questions are better,” he said chucking. When asked what the questions were over there he added laughing, “It’s the same shi-t every time.”
Of course, the biggest adjustment he’s had to make so far is moving permanently to America, and particularly North Carolina. He’s already noticed a great deal of differences between Australia and the U.S.
“The freaking cold,” he said laughing. “That’s been a shock coming from summer. I’ve never really lived in a place this cold.”
Saturday when he met with media at the National Motorsports Press Association’s annual convention in Charlotte where the high temperature was in the low 20s Saturday. In Australia it’s currently the middle of summer.
“It’s been nice otherwise, the weather’s been awesome,” he said. “Lots of cool places to go training, running, trail running and stuff.”
He said that while the food here will take a bit of getting used to, he hasn’t really missed any food from Australia, or New Zealand.
“You can get most things here,” he said. “Everything you get there’s a lot of; you just got to be disciplined I guess.”
Soon the NASCAR season will be underway starting with the biggest race of the season the Daytona 500. Shane van Gisbergen won’t be racing in the 500 on Sunday February 18, but he will be racing in the ARCA series and the Xfinity series in the days leading up to it. That Sunday he will be just a spectator in person for the first time. He, like many in New Zealand and Australia, has seen the race on TV.
“It’s probably the biggest NASCAR race to watch in that part of the world,” he said adding with a smile. “Until Chicago last year.”
Last season van Gisbergen won the NASCAR Cup series inaugural race on the streets of Chicago in his first Cup series start. For many drivers a win in your first race might have them setting their expectations high. That’s not the case for the newest resident of Mooresville.
“I don't I never go racing with expectations,” van Gisbergen said. “I don't know where I'm going to fit in or where I'm going to place you know.
“Just do my best and believe in my abilities.”

It’s official: Three-time Australian Supercars Champ Shane van Gisbergen is coming to America to race in NASCAR on a fulltime basis starting in 2024.
Trackhouse Racing announced Wednesday night that the winner of NASCAR’s inaugural Chicago Street Race will be part of a NASCAR development program with the team starting in 2024.
Trackhouse had the fielded the car for the 34-year-old Auckland, New Zealand native in Chicago as part of its PROJECT91 effort, a team dedicated solely to getting internationally renowned motorsports stars behind the wheel of a NASCAR racecar.
After that July 2 win, van Gisbergen said that after a “dream come true” weekend, he was open to the idea.
“I'm doing one more year in Oz [Supercars] and then I'd love to come over here,” he said at the time.
In his other NASCAR Cup series start he raced to a 10th-place finish on the road course at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on August 13. Two days prior he raced in the NASCAR Truck series at Indianapolis Raceway Park where he made his paved oval career debut. He kept a lead lap position until the final few laps, finishing 18th.
Shortly after returning to Australia, van Gisbergen and his Supercars team revealed that they would separate at the end of the season freeing van Gisbergen to come to America.
Trackhouse said the development program will include races in 2024 for van Gisbergen in NASCAR’s Cup, Xfinity and Craftsman Truck Series plus some late model and other races.
“This is going to be a tremendous challenge for Shane but he is a tremendous driver as we have all seen,” said Trackhouse Racing co-owner Justin Marks. “Next year will be about getting him acclimated to oval track racing, superspeedways, 1.5-mile tracks and everything he has never experienced in his career. It’s obviously going to be a learning process, but we think Shane will perform quite well.”
In a Supercars career that started in 2007, to date van Gisbergen has won 80 races in 501 starts along with 47 pole positions making him the fourth most successful driver in series history. He also won the Bathurst 1000 in 2020 and 2022. He won his first Supercars championship in 2016 and the 2021 and 2022 titles.
“This announcement means so many things to me,” van Gisbergen said.
“I’m proud of what I have achieved here in Australia, but I’m excited by this new chapter in my career and the opportunities that it brings.
“I’m so thankful to everyone who has played a role in my career so far, especially Triple Eight Race Engineering, and looking forward to finishing our year with a few more highlights.
“It is time for a new challenge and this adventure into NASCAR will be the biggest challenge of my career and one I’m really looking forward to. I want to thank Justin Marks (Trackhouse founder and owner) and everyone at Trackhouse Racing who have taken a chance on me and given me this opportunity. I’m excited to get to America and getting the season started.”

argos_summary: Trackhouse Racing has announced a multiyear contract extension with Shane van Gisbergen, the New Zealand driver who made a remarkable entry into NASCAR by winning his first Cup Series start in 2023. After a successful year racing full-time in the Xfinity Series, van Gisbergen will now compete full-time in the Cup Series, driving the No. 88 car, previously associated with Dale Earnhardt Jr. His rapid success has made him a standout in NASCAR, and Trackhouse Racing is expanding to a third team to accommodate him, solidifying their position as a competitive force in the sport.
